id-00007.label: Enhance Ability - Cat's Grace (C); ADVCHK: dexterity; No fall damage from 20'

id-00008.label: Enhance Ability - Eagle's Splendor (C); ADVCHK: charisma

id-00009.label: Enhance Ability - Fox's Cunning (C); ADVCHK: intelligence

id-00010.label: Enhance Ability - Owl's Wisdom (C); ADVCHK: wisdom

id-00034.components: V, S, M (fur or a feather from a beast)

description.p: You touch a creature and bestow upon it a magical enhancement. Choose one of the following effects; the target gains that effect until the spell ends.
Bear's Endurance.
The target has advantage on Constitution checks. It also gains 2d6 temporary hit points, which are lost when the spell ends.Bull's Strength.
The target has advantage on Strength checks, and his or her carrying capacity doubles.Cat's Grace.
The target has advantage on Dexterity checks. It also doesn't take damage from falling 20 feet or less if it isn't incapacitated.Eagle's Splendor.
The target has advantage on Charisma checks.Fox's Cunning.
The target has advantage on Intelligence checks.Owl's Wisdom.
The target has advantage on Wisdom checks.At Higher Levels.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

id-00034.name: Enhance Ability (T) (C)

description.p: You sense the presence of any trap within range that is within line of sight. A trap, for the purpose of this spell, includes anything that would inflict a sudden or unexpected effect you consider harmful or undesirable, which was specifically intended as such by its creator.

Thus, the spell would sense an area affected by the alarm spell, a glyph of warding, or a mechanical pit trap, but it would not reveal a natural weakness in the floor, an unstable ceiling, or a hidden sinkhole.
This spell merely reveals that a trap is present. You don't learn the location of each trap, but you do learn the general nature of the danger posed by a trap you sense.

You evoke a fiery blade in your free hand. The blade is similar in size and shape to a scimitar, and it lasts for the duration. If you let go of the blade, it disappears, but you can evoke the blade again as a bonus action. You can use your action to make a melee spell attack with the fiery blade. On a hit, the target takes 3d6 fire damage.
The flaming blade sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.
At Higher Levels.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for every two slot levels above 2nd.

id-00004.label: Flaming Sphere (C); SAVEEND: DEX DC ## (M) (H); SAVEDMG: 2d6 fire

id-00037.components: V, S, M (a bit of tallow, a pinch of brimstone, and a dusting of powdered iron)

description.p: A 5-foot-diameter sphere of fire appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within range and lasts for the duration. Any creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of the sphere must make a Dexterity saving throw.
The creature takes 2d6 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

As a bonus action, you can move the sphere up to 30 feet. If you ram the sphere into a creature, that creature must make the saving throw against the sphere's damage, and the sphere stops moving this turn.

When you move the sphere, you can direct it over barriers up to 5 feet tall and jump it across pits up to 10 feet wide. The sphere ignites flammable objects not being worn or carried, and it sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

id-00037.name: Flaming Sphere (60) (C) + =
id-00037.source: Cleric Light Domain, Druid, Eldritch Knight, Wizard, Arcane Trickster

id-00003.label: Gust of Wind (C); Failure results in 15ft push; SAVEO: STR DC ##

description.p: A line of strong wind 60 feet long and 10 feet wide blasts from you in a direction you choose for the spell's duration. Each creature that starts its turn in the line must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet away from you in a direction following the line. Any creature in the line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving closer to you.

The gust disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly and has a 50 percent chance to extinguish them.
As a bonus action on each of your turns before the spell ends, you can change the direction in which the line blasts from you.

id-00038.name: Gust of Wind (S-60) (C) + =
id-00038.source: Cleric Tempest Domain, Druid, Eldritch Knight, Monk, Sorcerer, Wizard, Arcane Trickster

description.p: You call forth a nature spirit to soothe the wounded. The intangible spirit appears in a space that is a 5-foot cube you can see within range. The spirit looks like a transparent beast or fey (your choice).

Until the spell ends, whenever you or a creature you can see moves into the spirit's space for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can cause the spirit to restore 1d6 hit points to that creature (no action required). The spirit can't heal constructs or undead.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the spirit up to 30 feet to a space you can see.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

id-00040.components: V, S, M (a piece of iron and a flame)

description.p: Choose a manufactured metal object, such as a metal weapon or a suit of heavy or medium metal armor, that you can see within range. You cause the object to glow red-hot. Any creature in physical contact with the object takes 2d8 fire damage when you cast the spell. Until the spell ends, you can use a bonus action on each of your subsequent turns to cause this damage again.

If a creature is holding or wearing the object and takes the damage from it, the creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or drop the object if it can. If it doesn't drop the object, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of your next turn.
At Higher Levels.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 2nd.

id-00040.name: Heat Metal (60) (C)

id-00004.label: Hold Person (C); Paralyzed; SAVEEND: WIS DC ##

id-00041.components: V, S, M (a small, straight piece of iron)

description.p: Choose a humanoid that you can see within range.

The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be paralyzed for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional humanoid for each slot level above 2nd. The humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

id-00041.name: Hold Person (60) (C) +
id-00041.source: Bard, Cleric, Druid, Druid Arctic Circle, Eldritch Knight, Monk, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard, Arcane Trickster

description.p: You touch a creature and can end either one disease or one condition afflicting it. The condition can be blinded, deafened, paralyzed, or poisoned.

id-00042.name: Lesser Restoration (T)
id-00042.source: Bard, Cleric, Cleric Life Domain, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Artificer

id-00043.components: V, S, M (a bit of fur from a bloodhound)

description.p: Describe or name a specific kind of beast or plant.
Concentrating on the voice of nature in your surroundings, you learn the direction and distance to the closest creature or plant of that kind within 5 miles, if any are present.

id-00043.name: Locate Animals or Plants (S)

description.p: Describe or name an object that is familiar to you. You sense the direction to the object's location, as long as that object is within 1,000 feet of you. If the object is in motion, you know the direction of its movement.

The spell can locate a specific object known to you, as long as you have seen it up close-within 30 feet-at least once. Alternatively, the spell can locate the nearest object of a particular kind, such as a certain kind of apparel, jewelry, furniture, tool, or weapon.
This spell can't locate an object if any thickness of lead, even a thin sheet, blocks a direct path between you and the object.

id-00044.name: Locate Object (S) (C)
id-00044.source: Bard, Cleric, Druid, Eldritch Knight, Paladin, Ranger, Wizard, Arcane Trickster

id-00045.components: V, S, M (several seeds of any moonseed plant and a piece of opalescent feldspar)

description.p: A silvery beam of pale light shines down in a 5-foot radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within range. Until the spell ends, dim light fills the cylinder. When a creature enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it is engulfed in ghostly flames that cause searing pain, and it must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes 2d10 radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
A shapechanger makes its saving throw with disadvantage. If it fails, it also instantly reverts to its original form and can't assume a different form until it leaves the spell's light.
On each of your turns after you cast this spell, you can use an action to move the beam up to 60 feet in any direction.
At Higher Levels:
when you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d10 for each slot level above 2nd.

id-00045.name: Moonbeam (120) (C) + =

id-00046.components: V, S, M (ashes from a burned leaf of mistletoe and a sprig of spruce)

description.p: A veil of shadows and silence radiates from you, masking you and your companions from detection. For the duration, each creature you choose within 30 feet of you (including you) has a +10 bonus to Dexterity (Stealth) checks and can't be tracked except by magical means. A creature that receives this bonus leaves behind no tracks or other traces of its passage.

id-00046.name: Pass without Trace (S) (C) =
id-00046.source: Cleric Trickery Domain, Druid, Druid Grassland Circle, Monk, Ranger

id-00001.label: Protection from Poison; RESIST: poison; advantage against being poisoned

description.p: You touch a creature. If it is poisoned, you neutralize the poison. If more than one poison afflicts the target, you neutralize one poison that you know is present, or you neutralize one at random.
For the duration, the target has advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and it has resistance to poison damage.

You cause up to ten words to form in a part of the sky you can see. The words appear to be made of cloud and remain in place for the spell's duration. The words dissipate when the spell ends. A strong wind can disperse the clouds and end the spell early.

id-00049.components: V, S, M (seven sharp thorns or seven small twigs, each sharpened to a point)

description.p: The ground in a 20-foot radius centered on a point within range twists and sprouts hard spikes and thorns. The area becomes difficult terrain for the duration. When a creature moves into or within the area, it takes 2d4 piercing damage for every 5 feet it travels. The transformation of the ground is camouflaged to look natural. Any creature that can't see the area at the time the spell is cast must make a Wisdom (Perception) check against your spell save DC to recognize the terrain as hazardous before entering it.

id-00049.name: Spike Growth (150) (C) =
id-00049.source: Cleric Nature Domain, Druid, Druid Arctic Circle, Druid Mountain Circle, Ranger

description.p: A strong wind (20 miles per hour) blows around you in a 10-foot radius and moves with you, remaining centered on you. The wind lasts for the spells duration.
The wind has the following effects:

list.li: It deafens you and other creatures in its area.
It extinguishes unprotected flames in its area that are torch-sized or smaller.
It hedges out vapor, gas, and fog that can be dispersed by strong wind.
The area is difficult terrain for creatures other than you.
The attack rolls of ranged weapon attacks have disadvantage if the attacks pass in or out of the wind.

description.p: Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

While this vessel is on your person, you can use an action to speak its command word and regain one expended spell slot. If the expended slot was of 4th level or higher, the new slot is 3rd level. Once you have used the vessel, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

id-00052.name: Biosis Vessel
id-00052.nonidentified: A large pearl, completely smooth and shining with an unnatural lustre.

description.p: You regain 2d4 + 2 hit points when you drink this potion. The potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.
Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

id-00053.name: Item: Potion of Healing
id-00053.nonidentified: A vial of red liquid that shimmers when agitated.

id-00001.label: Potion of Poison Resistance; RESIST: poison

description.p: When you drink this potion, you gain resistance to poison damage for 1 hour.
Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

id-00054.name: Item: Potion of Poison Resistance
id-00054.nonidentified: This vial contains a liquid with a slightly green tinge to it.

description.p: (Contact). This poison must be harvested from a dead or incapacitated carrion crawler. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 minute. The poisoned creature is paralyzed. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

id-00002.label: Antitoxin; Advantage on saves against poison

description.p: A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs.

(Contact). A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 24 hours. The poisoned creature is unconscious. The creature wakes up if it takes damage.

id-00003.label: Pale Tincture; Poisoned; Repeat save every 24 hours

description.p: (Ingested). A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take 3 (1d6) poison damage and become poisoned. The poisoned creature must repeat the saving throw every 24 hours, taking 3 (1d6) poison damage on a failed save. Until this poison ends, the damage the poison deals can't be healed by any means. After seven successful saving throws, the effect ends and the creature can heal normally.

id-00002.name: Weapon: Clubs, daggers, darts, javelins, maces, quarterstaffs, scimitars, sickles, slings, spears

id-00004.name: Armor: light armor, medium armor, shields (druids will not wear armor or use shields made of metal)

racelink.recordname: reference.racedata.half_elf_variant@D&D Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide - Player's Guide

text.p: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can't put you to sleep.
You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.

id-00001.desc: The guard drake makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Bite

id-00003.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage.
id-00003.name: Tail

text.p: A guard drake is a reptilian creature created out of dragon scales by means of a bizarre and grisly ritual. When trained properly, a drake is obedient, loyal, and territorial, which makes it an excellent watch-beast that can follow simple commands.

Gifts from Dragons. The ritual to create a guard drake was originally devised by the cult of Tiamat, but has spread to other groups that are skilled in arcana and associated with dragons. The cooperation of a dragon is necessary for the ritual to succeed, and a dragon typically provides its help when it wants to reward its allies or worshipers with a valuable servant.

The ritual, which takes several days, requires 10 pounds of fresh dragon scales (donated by the dragon allied with the group), a large amount of fresh meat, and an iron cauldron. When the process is complete, a halfling-sized egg emerges from the cauldron and is ready to hatch within a few hours.

Eager to Learn. A newly hatched guard drake imprints upon the first creature that feeds it (usually the one planning to train it), establishing an aggressive but trusting bond with that individual. A guard drake is fully grown within two to three weeks and can be trained in the same length of time. One is the equivalent of a guard dog in terms of what it can be trained to do.
A guard drake resembles the type of dragon it was created from, but with a wingless, squat, muscular build. A drake can't reproduce, nor can its scales be used to make other guard drakes.

Each type of chromatic dragon's scales and blood creates a guard drake that resembles a wingless, stunted version of that type of dragon, with unique abilities related to that type. Each has the special features described below.
Black Guard Drake. A black guard drake is amphibious (it can breathe air or water), has a swimming speed of 30 feet, and has resistance to acid damage.
Blue Guard Drake. A blue guard drake has a burrowing speed of 20 feet and resistance to lightning damage.
Green Guard Drake. A green guard drake is amphibious (it can breathe air or water), has a swimming speed of 30 feet, and has resistance to poison damage.
Red Guard Drake. A red guard drake has climbing speed of 30 feet and resistance to fire damage.
White Guard Drake. A white guard drake has a burrowing speed of 20 feet, a climbing speed of 30 feet, and resistance to cold damage.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) piercing damage plus 7 (2d6) poison damage.
id-00001.name: Bite

id-00002.desc: The greenspawn leaper discharges a cloud of poisonous gas in a 15-foot radius circle centered on itself. Each creature in the area other than the greenspawn leaper must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw, taking 17 (5d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
id-00002.name: Poison Burst (Recharge 5-6)

id-00007.name: Greenspawn Leaper

id-00001.desc: When the greenspawn leaper takes melee weapon damage and Poison Burst is available, it uses Poison Burst.
id-00001.name: Instinctive Poison Burst

id-00007.senses: blindsight 10 ft., darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 13

text.p: The greenspawn leaper resembles a 4-foot long wingless green dragon that has had its body streamlined for traveling among tree branches.

Arboreal Assassins. Leapers prefer to live in warm forests. They hunt alone or in groups by traversing across the treetops looking for prey on the ground. When they find a likely target they will ambush it by dropping down with a killing bite. As a last resort they will also emit a burst of poison gas that affects all adjacent targets. This is usually reserved for escape since the gas would ruin the flesh of the victim and render it inedible for the leapers.

id-00001.desc: The greenspawn leaper can breathe air and water.
id-00001.name: Amphibious

id-00002.desc: The greenspawn leaper's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 20 feet, with or without a running start.
id-00002.name: Standing Leap

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) piercing damage plus 7 (2d6) poison damage.
id-00001.name: Bite

id-00002.desc: The drake exhales gas in a 15foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature can't use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can't make more than one attack on its turn. In addition, the creature can use either an action or a bonus action on its turn, but not both. These effects last for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself with a successful save.
id-00002.name: Slowing Breath (Recharge 5-6)

id-00008.name: Ambush Drake
id-00008.senses: blindsight 10 ft., darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 12

text.p: Ambush drakes are often found in the service of Draconicspeaking creatures, such as kobolds and lizardfolk. They are either used as guards or as trackers.

Ambush Hunters. In the wild, ambush drakes hunt in packs, often dividing their numbers - one group to lie waiting in ambush while another to drive their prey to the ambush spot. Ambush drakes use a combination of its poisonous bite and slowing breath to immobilize their targets as the rest of the pack swoop in for the kill.

id-00001.desc: The drake has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.
id-00001.name: Ambusher

id-00001.desc: The deinonychus makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Bite

id-00003.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) slashing damage.
id-00003.name: Claw

text.p: This larger cousin of the velociraptor kills by gripping its target with its claws and feeding while the creature is still alive.

id-00001.desc: If the deinonychus moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. If the target is prone, the deinonychus can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.
id-00001.name: Pounce

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 1 piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Bite

id-00002.desc: The dragon exhales a puff of euphoria gas at one creature within 5 feet of it. The target must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw, or for 1 minute, the target can't take reactions and must roll a d6 at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior during the turn: 1- 4. The target takes no action or bonus action and uses all of its movement to move in a random direction. 5- 6. The target doesn't move, and the only thing it can do on its turn is make a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.
id-00002.name: Euphoria Breath (Recharge 5-6)

id-00001.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a pinch of powder or sand that is colored red, yellow, and blue)
Duration: 1 round
Range: Self (15-foot cone)
A dazzling array of flashing, colored light springs from your hand. Roll 6d10; the total is how many hit points of creatures this spell can effect. Creatures in a 15-foot cone originating from you are affected in ascending order of their current hit points (ignoring unconscious creatures and creatures that can't see).
Starting with the creature that has the lowest current hit points, each creature affected by this spell is blinded until the end of your next turn. Subtract each creature's hit points from the total before moving on to the creature with the next lowest hit points. A creature's hit points must be equal to or less than the remaining total for that creature to be affected.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, roll an additional 2d10 for each slot level above 1st.
id-00001.name: Color Spray (1/day)

id-00002.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a bit of phosphorus or wychwood, or a glowworm)
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
Range: 120 feet
You create up to four torch-sized lights within range, making them appear as torches, lanterns, or glowing orbs that hover in the air for the duration. You can also combine the four lights into one glowing vaguely humanoid form of Medium size. Whichever form you choose, each light sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the lights up to 60 feet to a new spot within range. A light must be within 20 feet of another light created by this spell, and a light winks out if it exceeds the spell's range.
id-00002.name: Dancing Lights (1/day)

id-00003.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 30 feet
A spectral, floating hand appears at a point you choose within range. The hand lasts for the duration or until you dismiss it as an action. The hand vanishes if it is ever more than 30 feet away from you or if you cast this spell again.
You can use your action to control the hand. You can use the hand to manipulate an object, open an unlocked door or container, stow or retrieve an item from an open container, or pour the contents out of a vial. You can move the hand up to 30 feet each time you use it.
The hand can't attack, activate magic items, or carry more than 10 pounds.
id-00003.name: Mage Hand (1/day)

id-00004.desc:
Level: 3
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a bit of fleece)
Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes
Range: 120 feet
You create the image of an object, a creature, or some other visible phenomenon that is no larger than a 20-foot cube. The image appears at a spot that you can see within range and lasts for the duration. It seems completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to the thing depicted. You can't create sufficient heat or cold to cause damage, a sound loud enough to deal thunder damage or deafen a creature, or a smell that might sicken a creature (like a troglodyte's stench).
As long as you are within range of the illusion, you can use your action to cause the image to move to any other spot within range. As the image changes location, you can alter its appearance so that its movements appear natural for the image. For example, if you create an image of a creature and move it, you can alter the image so that it appears to be walking. Similarly, you can cause the illusion to make different sounds at different times, even making it carry on a conversation, for example.
Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and its other sensory qualities become faint to the creature.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the spell lasts until dispelled, without requiring your concentration.
id-00004.name: Major Image (1/day)

id-00005.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: S, M (a bit of fleece)
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 30 feet
You create a sound or an image of an object within range that lasts for the duration. The illusion also ends if you dismiss it as an action or cast this spell again.
If you create a sound, its volume can range from a whisper to a scream. It can be your voice, someone else's voice, a lion's roar, a beating of drums, or any other sound you choose. The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends.
If you create an image of an object-such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest-it must be no larger than a 5-foot cube. The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it.
If a creature uses its action to examine the sound or image, the creature can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the illusion becomes faint to the creature.
id-00005.name: Minor Illusion (1/day)

id-00006.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: 1 minute
Range: Self
Three illusory duplicates of yourself appear in your space. Until the spell ends, the duplicates move with you and mimic your actions, shifting position so it's impossible to track which image is real. You can use your action to dismiss the illusory duplicates.
Each time a creature targets you with an attack during the spell's duration, roll a d20 to determine whether the attack instead targets one of your duplicates.
If you have three duplicates, you must roll a6 or higher to change the attack's target to a duplicate. With two duplicates, you must roll an 8 or higher. With one duplicate, you must roll an 11 or higher.
A duplicate's AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier. If an attack hits a duplicate, the duplicate is destroyed. A duplicate can be destroyed only by an attack that hits it.
It ignores all other damage and effects. The spell ends when all three duplicates are destroyed.
A creature is unaffected by this spell if it can't see, if it relies on senses other than sight, such as blindsight, or if it can perceive illusions as false, as with truesight.
id-00006.name: Mirror Image (1/day)

id-00007.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, M (a snake's tongue and either a bit of honeycomb or a drop of sweet oil)
Duration: Concentration, up to 8 hours
Range: 30 feet
You suggest a course of activity (limited to a sentence or two) and magically influence a creature you can see within range that can hear and understand you.
Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this effect. The suggestion must be worded in such a manner as to make the course of action sound reasonable.
Asking the creature to stab itself, throw itself onto a spear, immolate itself, or do some other obviously harmful act ends the spell.
The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it pursues the course of action you described to the best of its ability. The suggested course of action can continue for the entire duration. If the suggested activity can be completed in a shorter time, the spell ends when the subject finishes what it was asked to do. You can also specify conditions that will trigger a special activity during the duration. For example, you might suggest that a knight give her warhorse to the first beggar she meets. If the condition isn't met before the spell expires, the activity isn't performed.
If you or any of your companions damage the target, the spell ends.
id-00007.name: Suggestion (1/day)

text.p: A faerie dragon is a cat-sized dragon with butterfly wings. It wears a sharp-toothed grin and expresses its delight by the twitching of its tail, its merriment fading only if it is attacked.

Invisible Tricksters. The only warning of a faerie dragon's presence is a stifled giggle. The dragon stays out of sight, watching invisibly as its victims contend with its pranks. When its fun is done, the dragon might reveal itself, depending on the disposition of its "prey."

Friendly and Bright. A faerie dragon has a sharp mind, a fondness for treasure and good company, and a puckish sense of humor. Travelers can play to a faerie dragon's draconic nature by offering it "treasure" in the form of sweets, baked goods, and baubles in exchange for information or safe passage through its territory.

The Colors of Age. A faerie dragon's scales change hue as it ages, moving through all the colors of the rainbow. All faerie dragons have innate spellcasting ability, gaining new spells as they mature.

id-00001.desc: As a bonus action, the dragon can magically turn invisible until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the dragon wears or carries is invisible with it.
id-00001.name: Superior Invisibility

id-00002.desc: Using telepathy, the dragon can magically communicate with any other faerie dragon within 60 feet of it.
id-00002.name: Limited Telepathy

id-00003.desc: The dragon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
id-00003.name: Magic Resistance

id-00004.desc: The dragon's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma. It can innately cast a number of spells, requiring no material components:\n1/day each: color spray, dancing lights, mage hand, major image, minor illusion, mirror image, suggestion
id-00004.name: Innate Spellcasting

id-00001.desc: The clawfoot makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Bite

id-00003.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) slashing damage.
id-00003.name: Claws

id-00011.name: Clawfoot

sourcelink.recordname: reference.npcdata.clawfoot@DD Eberron Rising From the Last War - DM

link.recordname: image.img_clawfoot_jpg@DD Eberron Rising From the Last War - DM

text.p: Clawfoot dinosaurs are two-legged saurians with sharp teeth and toe claws that resemble deadly sickles. They are imposing creatures, about the size of a tall human, and are fierce enough to take down even larger prey.

In the wild, an untrained clawfoot can easily hold its own in combat, but they are even fiercer when hunting in packs. Their instinct for pack structure has made these dinosaurs a traditional war mount for the halflings of the Talenta Plains, with clawfoots quickly and eagerly responding to training and control.

Dinosaurs are widespread on Eberron, particularly in Q'barra, the Talenta Plains, Xen'drik, and Argonnessen. Smaller dinosaurs are the rule in Q'barra and the Talenta Plains, including varieties commonly used by Talenta halflings as mounts.

id-00011.token: tokens/clawfoot.png@DD Eberron Rising From the Last War - DM

id-00001.desc: The clawfoot has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the clawfoot's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.
id-00001.name: Pack Tactics

id-00002.desc: If the clawfoot moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a DC 11 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. If the target is prone, the clawfoot can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.
id-00002.name: Pounce

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage or 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage if used with two hands. Or Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Spear

text.p: Guards include members of a city watch, sentries in a citadel or fortified town, and the bodyguards of merchants and nobles.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage or 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage if used with two hands. Or Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Spear

text.p: Guards include members of a city watch, sentries in a citadel or fortified town, and the bodyguards of merchants and nobles.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage or 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage if used with two hands. Or Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Spear

text.p: Guards include members of a city watch, sentries in a citadel or fortified town, and the bodyguards of merchants and nobles.
Lorum Ipsum

p.i: The stone walls of this area seem to have been built around the same time as the buildings above. There are scuffs in the dirt floor that indicate large boxes have been moved around the space frequently. Along the walls, wooden crates are stacked bearing a logo of a cat eye with Smiling Sundries stenciled on them in common. To the north and east are metal doors, and to the south is a wooden door with a sign that says CAUTION: NO ENTRY in common as well as a set of stairs leading up.

text.p: This section of the underground sits directly beneath the store house. It is used by the sundries shop as overflow stock storage.
The crates in the room are filled with 3d100GP worth of various adventuring gear and shelf-stable rations. They can be opened with the help of a crowbar.

p.i: This room is filled with large wooden barrels labelled as mead, ale and beer. A ladder in the center of the room ascends to a hatch in the wooden ceiling.

text.p: The connecting room to the main storage area is used by the tavern to store extra drink casks. The hatch in the ceiling leads to the taverns pantry. The door opens inward and is blocked from the inside by heavy full casks, which need to be moved before the DC20 locked door can be opened. The key for this door is on the keyrings held by the bar staff and the sundries shop owner.
It looks like someone began to remove dirt here to create a new basement but never finished - the walls and floor are loose dirt and stones.

There is a pick axe and a bag containing dynamite and a key to area B in this area, in a small tunnel in the Northeast corner. The tight tunnel leading to it is unstable and will collapse if not navigated carefully, trapping anyone in the tunnel underneath.

p.i: This area seems to have been modified from a naturally occuring cave - the walls are uneven, and shadowy cracks and crevices lead to small dark holes that light refuses to reach. Strewn around the floor are discarded bones, hair, feces and scraps of fabric, suffusing the air with an unnerving putrescence. The muffled sound of squeaking comes from all around.

text.p: These caves are blocked off behind a DC20 locked metal door. The only key to this area is in area A3. The holes in the wall and ceiling of this area have become home to a large nest

This cave splits into left and right paths. The walls here are dotted with rat nest holes, and a mix of regular and mutated giant rats are hiding in them. If the party aggravates the rat swarms in the weapon cache room, they will come out of their holes and attack the party. Investigating the holes will reveal the encounter loot.

p.i: Before it was overrun with rats, this area seems to have been a weapons cache. The metal racks and hooks on the walls are now empty. A wooden bench with a knife and morning star resting on it is all thats left in the room.

text.p: The rats have made this cave their nest, they occupy a cluttered pile of rusted metal and scraps of wood and fabric. The nest on the floor of this area is difficult terrain.

Upon someone disturbing their nest, the rats will swarm and attack the intruders. Once any of them reach half health, they will begin squealing loudly, alerting the rest of the rats in the area, who will begin to pour out of the holes in the walls of the cave. The rats will continue to fight until they are killed off.
The only weapons left in this area are a rusted old dagger and a mageforged morning star on the bench. Moving into the room to obtain the weapons will aggravate the rats.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owners will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage.
The rusted old dagger is actually a vicious dagger, however its special properties are unusable until it has been restored by a smith.

The sounds of creaking wood, footsteps, and muffled voices emanate from the cobwebbed wooden ceiling here. Occasionally you can hear what sound like shouts and cheers. A thick layer of dirt coats the walls and floor, obscuring the stonework. Cracks of light project down from above and lace the ground, capturing motes of floating dust.

This area is directly beneath the taverns first floor, and the sounds of the patrons above carry down through the floorboards. The eastern half of the space is being used as a storage and tinkering area by the smugglers, and the west chamber has been left abandoned due to its proximity to the giant spiders web.
The wooden ceiling of this room is barely 7 feet high. Dark tunnels lead off from it to the North and Northwest, and in the Southeast, dim lantern light flickers from around a corner.
The ceiling of this room is only six and a half feet high, and there are a large number of cobwebs crisscrossing it.

A sleeping Kobold guard named Kiki is leaning against the wall of the Southeast tunnel - theyre supposed to be keeping watch for rats and the spider. The Kobold can be snuck past with a DC10 stealth check, but if awakened will alert the other Kobolds in the adjacent areas C2 and D.

There is a 5x5x10 foot hidden pit trap in this room at the entrance to the Northwest tunnel, disguised to match the material of the surrounding floor. The trap is rigged with bells, and setting off the trap will awaken the nearby sleeping Kobold guard. The sides of the pit are greased and require a DC20 Dexterity check to climb.

p.i: Sounds of clanking and Kobolds chattering echo from the north side of this room. They are bent over two open crates, comparing discarded components and pieces of junk. Strewn about the room are various strange contraptions that seem to approximate machines.

text.p: This room has been co-opted by a pair of Kobold Inventors named Brik and Brak as a tinkering space. They are preoccupied with two crates full of various odds and ends, and wont notice anyone sneaking past them through the southern end of the room. However, they will come to assist if the Kobolds in areas C1 or D raise an alert. If spied upon, they will be discussing various ideas for traps to place in the area, and may mention one of the monsters occupying the underground smuggling tunnels.

The inventors have a variety of small throwable traps strapped to their bodies, as well as laying about the space. When a player moves into a new square in the north part of the room, there is a 1d8 chance that they will inadvertently set off one of the traps they have left lying out on the ground (DEX 15 save to avoid the effects)

p.i: The wall here has crumbled away, creating a breach between the earth tunnel and a stone lined sewer.

text.p: This tunnel intersects with the sewer built into the base of the wall, area G. The rubble spills over into the area and acts as difficult terrain in the 10 feet surrounding the entrance.
This entrance to the sewer is guarded by the giant spider whose web fills the tunnel. Occasionally, a rat will wander in here from the sewer or area B, and their carcasses hang in the webs.
The tunnel leading North to this exit is filled with webs. A giant spider lives here and attempts to trap any creatures that come through this tunnel.

The Kobolds are aware of the spider (it caught and ate one) so will avoid following intruders into this tunnel. Occasionally rats will enter the tunnel, their carcasses are hanging from the walls and ceiling. The spider will hide in wait (DC20 to notice it) and will only attack once a creature has entered the tunnel. The webs here count as difficult terrain. Setting fire to the webs will quickly burn them, and flush the spider out of the tunnel whichever direction is away from the blaze. The spider can also be distracted with carcasses of fallen rats and kobolds from the area.
The unmistakable scent of Kobolds fills this area. Dirty cloth bedrolls lay out of the floor and burnt candle nubs litter the corners.

This room serves the smugglers as a base of operations on the south side of the wall. At any given time there are 4 Kobolds in this area, either sleeping, eating, or sorting contraband that they are in the process of transporting through the tunnels. They will defend themselves from any intruders that find their way down, calling the other Kobolds in the area. If it becomes obvious that they are outmatched, they will attempt to escape via area D1, and flee to the sub-basement though area H2.
The Kobolds have stored their loot in sacks near their sleeping area.
This section of the wall has been excavated to form a connection with the drains under the bath house, and is the main way that the Kobolds enter and exit the area.

A Kobold is always on guard in this area, watching the Northwest and East entrances to the area. It takes a DC20 stealth check to gain surprise on them. When the party enters the area, Drak the Kobold will be on duty. He is paranoid, and reacts immediately to any suspicious noises or flickers of shadow.

3 Kobolds are in this area, resting. There is a 1D4 chance that each of them is asleep. If so, they will begin an encounter surprised. The Kobolds in this area will attempt to defend themselves first, and stop the party from nearing or entering the stash room secondly.

Krag, Dirk, and Bok are in this area at the time that the party enters. Krag is a larger, more aggressive kobold than the others, and often bullies them. He is also more likely to fight to the death with any intruders, and when bloodied he flies into a rage and gains a +2 advantage on melee attacks and 5 temporary hit points. Bok is a coward and will avoid fighting up close if possible, putting the others in between him and an enemy. Dirk is surprisingly agile, and has a natural +2 advantage on dexterity checks, ranged attacks and AC. He enjoys taunting his foes from a distance but will surrender if cornered.

p.i: The walls and ceiling of this excavated dirt room are supported with dubious looking wooden slats. And boards. It is devoid of any furnishings with the exception of a large wooden chest and a lantern.
Effect | Drops 2 centipede swarms from the ceiling

text.p: The DC20 locked chest in this area contains the contraband that the smugglers are currently moving. Attempting to open the chest without first disarming the trap will trigger its effect. It is filled with 10d100GP worth of Basilisk Blood in small crystal vials. It also contains instructions for delivery of the drugs to the buyer. The key to the chest is on the Kobold Guard in area D2.

Basilisk Blood is a powerful sedative. Often used to numb pain for surgery, it is extremely popular recreationally as well due to its addictive nature. One dose completely removes all sensation of pain in the body, as well as creating a euphoric emotion in the user. It grants 1d6 temporary hit points and the user temporarily ignores being fatigued, frightened, stunned or exhausted.

After taking a dose, the user can move and act normally for another hour, enduring even debilitating pain. Afterwards they proceed to fall into a deep sleep for the following 4 hours, during which time it is almost impossible to wake them.

Every time a user takes this drug they run a 1d4 risk of becoming addicted. If a dose of Basilisk Blood isn't consumed once per day by an addict, they are afflicted with level 3 exhaustion (Disadvantage on ability checks, speed halved, disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws). An addiction can only be cured via magical means.

The drug is available in the Dragon States through exotic medicine sellers, at high price. It is outright banned within the Fey Dominion because of its impure nature. Nonetheless, the demand for it makes it a hot commodity on the smuggling market.

The Kobold smugglers have contracted with a Dominion black market dealer known as Quell. In the note, they have instructed the Kobolds to have the shipment ready for pickup at the dropoff point the following night at 10PM. Anyone trained in Thieves Cant will be able to identify the authenticity of the note. Quells name is known in the underground circles of the dragonside of the city as a dealer who is open to working with even the lowliest levels of criminals, up to and including rogue Kobolds.

p.i: These pipes are cramped and narrow, and coated with a thick layer of grime and mildew that sloughs off on anything that touches it. Water trickles down from rows of drain pipes in the ceiling. There is a muted sound of running water.

text.p: These drains service the bath house above. In the center of the intersecting cross there is an opening on the ceiling leading up to the broken tub. A rope hangs down, allowing someone to climb and get out with a DC10 strength check to move the wooden tub. The drains are just large enough for a medium size creature to squeeze through.

This is the main entrance that the Kobolds have been using to access the underground. A check of the area will reveal their footprints and claw marks throughout the area, and their soiled feet track mildew out into their den as well as into the sewer.

At any given time there is a 1d8 chance that the Kobold on guard in the adjacent area might come to patrol these pipes. If they encounter an intruder, they will attempt to run back to their den to alert the other Kobolds stationed there. The Kobolds will avoid fighting in this area if possible due to its constriction, but might block the party inside to force them into a disadvantage.
This section of the wall has been excavated to form a connection with the smugglers den in area D, and is the main way that the Kobolds enter and exit the area.

The pipe here bends up 90 degrees and continues straight up, where it connects with the floor drain in the tavern kitchen. It is just big enough for a small size creature to shimmy up and down. The pipe is climbable with a DC 15 dexterity check by anyone able to fit down it, however size medium and larger creatures cannot fit through it.

The kobolds have been using this pipe to steal food from the tavern food store in the Kitchen above, which they eat themselves as well as use to distract the Gelatinous Cube in the adjacent sewer tunnel. Inspection of the pipe will reveal their claw marks on the walls. The grate at the top is unscrewed and lifts off easily.

Smiling dropped her earring down one of the bathtub drain above. It is made of Pewter and has an ornament in the shape of a tiny bell on it. When worn, it grants a +4 to perception checks related to hearing. It is worth 320GP, or 400GP at Smiling Sundries (Southwall, area F).

p.i: This sewer appears to be crafted of the same type of stone as the Border Wall above. It runs straight, at a nearly imperceptible grade. Currently the water is only flowing a half inch deep. The walls, floor and low ceiling here look surprisingly clean, though somewhat slimy.

text.p: The sewer is built into the base of the wall, and is designed to remove waste water as well as reroute flood waters to the bay. This section has been breached on both sides, and has created a passthrough underneath the wall.

A young Gelatinous Cube has made its way into this stretch and has grown to the width of the sewer tunnel. It is not fully developed yet: it is only 5 feet to a side, moves at a rate of 10 feet per turn, and only does half damage when it attacks.

The cube will methodically chase any living creature that enters the tunnel, but can easily be distracted with food. It normally dwells around the Eastern end of the tunnel in between the two drain entrances, and the Kobolds have taken to using it as a sort of security door for their route. They use food stolen from the kitchen above to lure the cube down the tunnel, and then cross to the pipes on the other side.

The grates at either end of the sewer tunnel are sunk directly into the stonework and are solid steel. They require a full days worth of work with filing tools to dismantle. The grate bars are too close together for small creatures or larger to fit through. If anyone breaks through and traverses further into the sewers, they will find nothing of note and after a half mile of trekking will eventually find a storm drain with a metal rung ladder leading up to a random place aboveground.

Rubble spills over into the area from the tunnel leading to area C and acts as difficult terrain in the 10 feet surrounding the entrance. There are wisps of spider silk clinging to the area around this tunnel entrance.
See area C3 for information about the giant spider in the tunnel.

The pipe widens at the mouth and opens into the sewer here. This opening is too small for the Gelatinous Cube in the sewer to enter. Scrawled on the wall in poorly written Draconic is the word Feed, an instruction to use food to move the cube.

On the opposite side of the sewer from the basement, a second drain pipe runs north. The drain is just large enough for a medium sized creature to squeeze through. The Gelatinous Cube cannot fit into this opening.
The kobolds use this drain to access the lower portion of the underground route. There are marks on the floor and walls that indicate their movement through the area (DC10 perception to notice).

p.i: A narrow pipe, just wide enough to squeeze through, connects perpendicular to the main sewer here. There seems to be a slight upward grade to it and seems to connect to several more offshoots.

text.p: This section of the drains is designed to siphon overflow from the main sewer. It inclines gradually and is currently completely dry.

p.i: The walls of this section of pipe are uncomfortably tight around your arms, and force you to worm your way further. Something glimmers at the end in a pile of rubbish.
Effect | Pinned until save is made

text.p: This dead end acts like a trap, getting gradually tighter until anyone of small size or larger becomes stuck with their arms and legs pinned to their sides. Anyone who attempts to help someone trapped in this pipe also risks becoming trapped as well. The glimmer at the end is just from a piece of scrap metal.

p.i: The drain opens up here into a wider bell-shaped space. In the middle of the floor a large metal grate has rusted through, exposing an opening to a yawning dark shaft below. Cool damp air blows up through it. A worn looking braided hemp rope is tied off at the top to one of the rusted grate bars, and trails down the shaft into shadow.

text.p: This drain leads down to the overflow cistern 30 feet below. The kobolds have tied off a rope here, and use it to move up and down between the areas. Upon closer inspection, it is badly frayed. Anyone of size medium or larger attempting to use the rope runs a 1d4 risk of it snapping under their weight and dropping them down the shaft.

If investigated with a light source, the cistern full of water below is visible. Dropping anything down to disturb the water will alert the Water Weird in the cistern to intruders. Falling into the water does not cause damage, but will initiate an encounter with the elemental.
Kobold prints and claw marks are visible throughout this room. Scrawled on the wall in poorly written Draconic are the words Bad Water, a warning about the elemental in the cistern below.

If the Kobolds from area D surrender to the party, they will lead them to this area under the promise of showing them the north exit of the tunnels. They will attempt to get the party to go down the rope first, and if successful they will then cut the rope, dropping whoevers descending it directly into the pool below to encounter the awaiting water weird.

p.i: Our story opens in the common room of The Grinning Gander, a busy tavern in the shadow of the Drostellan border wall.

It's 7PM and the crowd inside the taproom is starting to get dense. A travelling elf bard going by the name "Summer Wind" is crooning to the gathered patrons, using magic to amplify his voice and float orbs of light out above the crowd for ambiance. The innkeeper gnome dodges between the legs of patrons and chairs to deliver drinks. Behind the bar, the orc bartender keeps the ale flowing. And, in the back corner of the room, a small group forms.

Youve been assembled here at the request of a mutual acquaintance. The man sitting across from you at the table is Randal Reyne, veteran member of The Rising and coordinator for Resistance operations in Dragonside. His reason for convening you: to assign you your first mission for the cause.

text.p: Once a quaint inn, The Grinning Gander is now notorious as a hotbed for rougher types. The current innkeeper is more interested in gambling, drinking games and general debauchery than he is in the upkeep of his inherited family business. Likewise, the patrons and staff both are on the seedier side, though generally good natured. This makes it the perfect location for resistance operatives to meet without the threat of discovery, as the volume and general chaos of the bar provide a level of anonymity.

Unknown to the bar staff, several entrances to the underground smuggling route are scattered across the property. Randal informs the party that his intel has isolated this block as the site of the tunnel, and their group has been chosen for an practical test of their skills in finding and securing the route. He says that they will be observed, and if successful they will be graduated to full members of the local Resistance branch.

p.i: The bar is crowded and loud, as Lelhallan is a commonly observed holiday for drunken celebration. All sorts of people are packed in, laughing and carousing. Getting space at the bar might be hard unless you are patient, or else shove through the crowd.

text.p: Behind the bar, an Orc bartender is serving drinks. Xugha Redbleeder is a large brutish figure with an imposing attitude, but his friend Zane Farlight, an obnoxious human barfly who always hangs out with him during his shifts, will attempt to get one or more of the party to bet on a game of cups with Xugha. Fortunately for them, he is poor at sleight of hand, and its fairly easy to win against him.

If Xugha loses as a game Zane will continue to egg the betters on, until 3 successful tries. At that point Xugha will be tapped out and throw his money pouch at the players in frustration. Inside the pouch are the winnings as well as the keys to the pantry and store house. If the party chooses to keep the keys, Xugha wont notice them missing until after his shift ends. However if they choose to return them they will win his favor and he will provide information about the Kobold smugglers.

Summer Wind is singing for the crowded taproom. A classically trained Elven bard, he considers this venue below his station - but an addiction to basilisk blood has caused him to fall on hard times. If the party engages with him between sets, he can be persuaded into talking to Fey members of the group but will likely ignore non-Fey. Upon entering a conversation with him he will have nothing of importance to say about the smuggling operation but will openly ask about them procuring him his drug of choice. If they can provide it to him he is more than willing to pay them for their troubles.

Podon Felhim, the Gnome innkeeper, is working the seating area as a server. While normally acting as the proprietor of the lodging side of the business, the Inns bad reputation has led to a dip in guests, and so he is now having to make up the difference with entertainment and service. He booked Summer Wind at great expense in an effort to drum up sales for the holiday.

While he has the businesses best interests at heart, his love of gambling and unseemly friends have led to a falling out between him and his mother, who used to be the innkeeper but now runs the bath house next door.

Podon is partial to games of skill, and is trying to organize competitions to drum up more business. If a character with a higher than average strength score approaches him, he will invite them to go upstairs and test their skills against the reigning armwrestling champion with Zuri. If they have a higher than average constitution score, he will send them to start a drinking competition with Earthbreaker. Otherwise, he will point them to a game of cards happening on the ground floor.
Podon carries a duplicate set of storage keys to the ones that Xugha has, but they are on his person and will need to be pickpocketed or otherwise stolen from him.

p.i: This room stores extra bottles and ingredients for the bar. A hatch that leads down to the Taverns Cask Cellar is set into the floor, and on the ceiling is a rope winch for moving casks up and down.

text.p: There is 450 GP worth of alcohol stored in bottles in this storage room, as well as various serving vessels and popular mixed drink ingredients.
The door to this room is locked with one of the storage keys held by the innkeeper and bartender. Sneaking into this room would be hard because it is in full visibility of the crowded bar.

This elevated loft wraps around the second floor of the inn, and is dimly lit with candles. This area overlooks the open first floor and many patrons crowd up here to drink and listen to the performance happening below.

In one corner, a crowd forms around Juri Rustmail, the local champion arm wrestler. She is a Dwarf trapper from The Deep that comes to town to sell off rare and exotic monster parts to arcane merchants. Her favorite activity is using her prowess with strength competitions to win money.

The party can engage her directly or at the suggestion of the innkeeper. She is competitive but jovial and friendly, and if they win she will congratulate them and offer them a deal: she is currently hunting for water elementals in order to harvest their nucleus to sell. If the party finds one and brings it to her, she will trade them for a fancy Dwarf treasure.

Earthbreaker, a goliath soldier, draws a crowd in the opposite corner. A member of the city guard, he is well known as a competitive drinker in his off time. He is boisterous, and openly challenges anyone who dares to try out-drinking him. However, he doesnt have much coin left after purchasing his drinks, and if he loses he will refuse to give the party any winnings.

Further engagement with him (or refusing to hand over their gold after losing to him) will cause Earthbreaker to attempt to begin a bar fight with his challenger. If this happens there is a 1d6 chance every round that the rest of the party will get sucked into an all-out bar brawl with whoever else is surrounding them. If the fight goes on too long, constables will show up at the bar and stop the fight, arresting whoevers involved.

p.i: These rented rooms are currently empty during the bar crawl hours of the evening. Noise from the common area seeps under the doors. They are sparsely outfitted with functional look beds and lockable storage chests.

text.p: There is a 1d4 chance that each room is currently rented out. If it is, the storage chest is locked with a DC15 lock. Roll on a random loot table for the contents.

The party begins this mission convening with one another for the first time as a splinter group. They are introduced to each other by a mutually trusted member of the Resistance - Randal Reyne, who serves as a private guard to a Dragonborn emissary for the Gilt Wyrm. Randal is a veteran of the local branch of The Rising, and is a coordinator for recruiting new members to the resistance efforts in Drostella. An avid reader and writer, Randal is educated beyond his station as a guard. The child of an escaped Dominion slave, he joined the resistance in his early 20s and has been active in numerous missions with the help of many factions. He is well known and liked within the community, with a reputation for always having something encouraging to say.

Before the start of the mission, each member of the team receives an individualized summons from Randal, asking them to meet him on the evening of Lelhallan (a major celebration in the Fey religious calendar) at The Grinning Gander, a tavern in Southwall. There, he says that they will be introduced to their new team and assigned their first official mission.

p.i: The chirping of crickets is audible in this small outdoor plot. It is bordered on all sides by buildings - to the north is the border wall, east is the back of the tavern, south is a squat looking stone building with a metal door, and west is the back of a private home with shuttered windows. There is a low wooden bench out here, and an old well stands in the corner.

text.p: This courtyard serves as an overflow area for the bar crowd. It is dimly illuminated by a few lanterns and there are deep shadows in the corners.

The well in the corner has come to serve as a urinal for the bar patrons, and if inspected smells somewhat foul of urine. There is nothing of particular interest in the bottom of the well, except a handful of wet copper coins and an annoyed non-monstrous rat that will attack anyone who tries to enter its nest.
This heavy metal door leads into the storehouse, and is locked with a DC20 lock. The bartender and innkeeper both have a copy of the key needed to unlock it.

p.i: This kitchen is filled with the smells of frying meat and stew. Aw, fuck, damn HOLD UP ITS ALMOST READY! A young human cook frantically runs between the prep tables, assembling dishes to serve the bar customers while muttering under his breath.

text.p: Gregory Twoorb, the one and only chef at The Grinning Gander, runs this kitchen in a state of organized chaos. Half finished meals are strewn across the tables here, and several large pots bubble on the hearth. He is in the middle of a dinner rush and doesnt have much time at all to talk to the party if they try to interrupt him. But, if they pester him long enough he will reveal that he is currently trying to catch a band of bandits that keep breaking into the kitchen to steal groceries, and points them to the food stores.

This large shelving unit is filled with different meal ingredients, everything from meat cuts and vegetables to spices and oils. However there are some conspicuously empty shelves near the bottom. Upon closer inspection, the party will notice some distinctive scratch marks that may be identified as Kobold marks with a skilled check.

This drain is set into the tile floor and is big enough to be squeezed through by a small sized creature. Closer inspection will reveal that the screws on it are loosened, allowing for the grate cover to be lifted and removed.
This hole connects to the secret tunnels that the Kobolds have been using to smuggle goods through the bath house, and they have been coming up through it to steal food for their secret base below.

p.i: A humid waft of air envelops you as soon as you step into this dimly lit building. The sound of running water emanates from several of the curtained stalls lined up against the walls, and it smells of soap. An elderly, disagreeable looking Gnome woman sits on a stool at the entrance. She squints at you and barks Five copper for a bath, and a silver for soap. Bring your own towel. And - no belts! Theyve been banned.

text.p: This bath house is run by Tamyra Felhim, the elderly mother of the innkeeper next door. She has had a falling out with her son and has now disowned the inn, instead choosing to run this public bathing facility.
She is cranky by default, though mainly just tired and disengaged. Being severely nearsighted, she hasnt even noticed that the Kobold smugglers have been using her business as a smuggling route.

Recently, her prized locket containing a portrait of her and her son as a baby went missing. If the party rounds the corner of the block and investigates the back alley behind the bath house, they will find a crow that has been playing with the locket. Upon scaring off the crow they can retrieve it and return it to her to gain her favor. She will then tell them about the large number of rude and smelly kobolds that have been using her baths recently.
The bath itself has seen better days. The stalls are dilapidated and some of the faucets dont seem to work. A mild mildew odor permeates the stalls.

There is a rack for hanging and drying clothes near the entrance as well as some wash tubs for doing laundry. If the party checks the clothing, roll on the random loot table to see what they find in the pockets.

This tub is visibly busted, with a sign reading OUT OF ORDER in common hanging from the stall curtain. Upon closer inspection the party will notice that a hole is concealed under the tub base. The hole is large enough for a medium sized creature to squeeze through, and leads down to the area under the bath house.

This is the secret entrance that the smugglers have been using to gain entrance to the underground. If the characters stake out the location, there is a 1d4 chance every hour that they will observe a Kobold entering or leaving the hole discreetly.

p.i: The inner perimeter of this reinforced building is lined with locked steel storage cages. Inside you can see chests, barrels and crates marked with the names of various companies in the neighborhood. The stone walls and floors show the scrapes and scuffs of a busy warehouse. In the center of the building, another metal door seems to lead to an inner vault.

text.p: This communal storehouse services the needs of the Southwall businesses. If the players sneak into this space there is a 1d4 chance that they encounter the miller from Area H lugging his meal inside to store it. He will attempt to identify who they are if he catches them, and if he realizes they are intruders he will run out the front of the building to alert the authorities.
These metal cages are eached secured with a DC15 padlock. The lockers that are currently in use each have 3d100 GP worth of trade goods stashed in them.

This door is secured from the outside with a DC20 lock. The only key is held by the sundries shopkeeper. The lock is charmed with a tamper alarm: if anyone attempts to unlock the door with a means other than the key without first disarming the spell it will create a loud ringing noise, alerting the shopkeeper as well as anyone else in the vicinity of the store house. The door is only able to be locked or unlocked from the outside.

p.i: Inside of this room, boxes labeled with the words Smiling Sundries, the name of the sundries shop next door have been piled high. Some random odds and ends are scattered around, and a set of stairs leads down into the floor.

text.p: This vault is used exclusively by the sundries shop next door. The wooden stairs here lead down to the basement in area A1. There are some miscellaneous adventuring supplies scattered around the room, as well as 2D100 worth of trade goods and an open chest filled with 540GP worth of coins, belonging to the shopkeeper.

This inner room is not visited as frequently as the storage lockers outside, and if the party is able to enter it without setting off the alarm they can spend an extended rest here without being disturbed.

p.i: This shop is filled to the brim with a strange assortment of tools, adventuring gear, weapons, books and other odds and ends. Dubious looking plate mail looms in the corners and on the floor an enormous bear pelt is spread out. The shopkeeper, a Tabaxi with striking spotted yellow fur, saunters about her store, shuffling and primping her wares.

text.p: This general store is owned by Smiling In The Face Of Death, a female Tabaxi merchant. Smiling is an odd creature, though she is well meaning. If the party shows any interest at all in her wares she will go off on a long, distracted tangent about the item, eventually drifting into non sequiturs. She is also quick to tell the party about a large shipment of fish she is receiving for unclear reasons, attempting to persuade them to place an advance order for some. Smiling has storage keys for the inner vault of the storage facility next door. She wont willingly part with them, but will leave them unattended at the cashiers table if she is distracted by a customer.

linklist.link: Smiling In The Face Of Death

text.p: This table is the point of sale for the shop. A small bag of change is out on the table, and underneath is a DC15 locked chest containing 1D100 GP worth of mixed coins. The key to the chest is on the same ring as the other shop keys.
This metal door is locked with a DC15 lock, the key for it is on Smilings keyring. Smiling will notice anyone attempting to unlock the door unless distracted somewhere else in the shop.

This shelf is stocked with spell scrolls that ostensibly do what theyre labeled with. In reality they are poorly transcribed and have a 1d6 chance of being a dud. Several of them actually do something different than they are labeled.If asked about any of the scrolls on the shelf, Smiling will go on a long winded tangent about it.

A cloying mix of smoke scents wreaths the interior of this small shop. Across a large wooden table a young goblin woman sits filing her nails. Whatchya afta? She drawls as she finally looks up to notice you. We got blends of everything fresh in stock yestaday. Good shit right hea.
This small store sells mixtures of special herbs that, when inhaled as smoke, can provide temporary buffs to natural abilities. They also stock a wide variety of pipes.

Each blend is good for 3 uses. When someone inhales the smoke, their base ability scores associated with the blend will be increased and decreased by 1 point respectively for the following 2 hours. All associated scores and modifiers to the stats will also be temporarily changed. Buffs will stack (both positive and negative) with the exception that the same blend cannot be stacked with itself.

For every use of a particular blend after the first time a player uses it in the span of a month, there is a cumulative 1D8 chance that they become addicted (on a roll of 1 through 3 the third time, 1 through 6 the sixth time, etc) If a user is currently addicted, they will need to use the blend constantly or else suffer a -2 penalty to the buffed score associated with that blend. Addiction penalties stack the same as buffs. A user can make a constitution saving throw with disadvantage once per day to overcome their addiction; alternatively they can be cured with cure disease.

Agna, the goblin shopkeeper, is bored and will try to gossip with the players if they choose to engage her. She has a crush on the Orc bartender Xugha, and will talk about the beefcake next door that she wants a date with. However she dislikes Zane and will discuss how he is desperate for attention and easy to manipulate.

p.i: The curb of the busy street bells out here at the entrance to this stone building. To the left of the entrance, a scrawny old Kobold clangs a wooden ladle against a large metal cauldron, hawking slurry to passerby. On the right, a cart full of milled grain is parked.

text.p: This is the front entrance to the store house. The door is currently unlocked, as a miller is moving his wares into the building. If the party returns later, it is locked with a DC15 lock that can be opened with the keys held by the tavern employees and the shopkeeper.

p.i: SLUUUUURRRR-RY! SLUUUURRRRR-RY Squawks the Kobold as his bubbling mixture . EAAT! GOOOD!

text.p: A Kobold named Krik is selling slurry (a dish popular with Draconic creatures) by the side of the road here for 2CP a cup. He doesnt have a sense of taste, and anyone who eats the slurry must make a CON saving throw against regurgitating it due to the rancid flavor.

Krik is secretly a member of the smugglers that are running operations in the underground tunnels. Their slurry stand is a cover to keep watch on the surface. If successfully persuaded (bribed) or intimidated (threatened) they will offer information about the entrance to the tunnels hidden in the bath house. However they will not reveal anything related to the particulars of their plans. If the party attempts to engage with combat, they will throw their ladle at the nearest enemy and attempt to flee.

A half orc miller named Hern Volster is currently lugging his wares off this cart and into the storehouse via the front entrance. Hern is tired from a long work day and wont pay much attention to anyone outside the entrance to the building, however he will attempt to run off anyone who tampers with his cart.

p.i: Well worn wheel ruts in the cobblestone street lead up to the entrance of this cul-de-sac. To the Northwest, the open doors of The Grinning Gander stream light and laughter out into the evening. To the Northeast stands a dilapidated looking building with a sign showing a bucket and scrub brush, indicating that it is a public bath house. A small smoke shop occupies the Southwest corner, and the West side is framed in by a stately looking moneychangers office.

text.p: This area leads to the main entrance of the tavern and the neighboring businesses. A good number of people come and go through this area - if the party spends enough time observing the flow of traffic they will see people of various types coming and going from the bar, as well as a few entering and leaving the other establishments. There is a 1d8 chance they will see a Kobold smuggler carrying a suspicious looking bundle in or out of the bath house.

p.i: Finely crafted mahogany floors and luxurious wallpaper adorn this lofty office. Plants, leather bound books and curios adorn the North and South walls. In the middle of the room at a polished wood desk sits a distinguished looking Dwarf. His beard and mustache are intricately braided brass coils. Hmmm yes, and how might I help you today? He says as he stands up to greet you. Looking for a change of coin?

text.p: This office is the business place of Umibol Bottlebringer, a money changer. Umibol services merchants and traders looking to exchange coinage in the Trade District. He is quite successful in his profession and will be cordial with any party members who look like they may potentially have finances matching his usual clientele. If questioned, he will complain about the Kobolds frequenting the bath house next door. He doesnt trust them to be above-board, and will encourage the party to investigate them and potentially remove them as a pest.

p.i: A placid pool of dark water fills the cistern in the middle of this cross-shaped room. It is framed in by four columns supporting the vaulted ceiling, in the center of which is a dark shaft going directly up. Along the walls and cistern wall runs a painted plaster frieze, depicting bas-relief hands raising up to touch a stylized band of flames.

text.p: The pool in this room acts as an overflow for the sewers above. The ridge of the cistern is 3 feet high, and the water level is 1 foot below floor level. The water is 20 feet deep. At the bottom of the cistern is a metal shutter used to drain the water. A metal level that operates the shutter is installed on the east column, facing towards the wall. The level is rusted, and requires a DC20 strength check to move. If it is flipped, the water level will go down by 3 feet per round.

The cistern has become home to a Water Weird, a type of elemental monster usually confined to The Deep. The elemental is bound to the water here, and will attack anyone who disturbs it. The Kobolds have learned how to climb and descend the shaft here without touching the water and have left the elemental alone. The elemental will fight until it is brought to 0 HP, or else when the water has been completely drained from the cistern. The elementals nucleus, a round orb of clear jelly-like substance with a blue gem at the center, is prized as an arcane ingredient. If the cistern is drained, it will be sucked out with the rest of the water. Otherwise, it will float on the surface of the water after the elemental is destroyed.
