The shaft in the ceiling of this room is inaccessible without the help of a rope tied off to the grate at the top - if it is snapped or cut anyone at the bottom will have to find an alternative route back up.

The door to the north of this room is unlocked and leads to the book shop basement (area K). The door to the south is protected by a magic ward, opening only to members of the defunct cult of Telerus that used to occupy this area, which was led by the book shop owner. The door bears the mark of Telerus (cupped hands holding a flame) and has a 2 inch depression in the middle of the symbol. Inserting a signet of Telerus will suppress the spell.
A Religion check will reveal this about the cult of Telerus:

p.i: the cult was once a widespread religion centered around the planar deity Telerus, the flamebringer. Telerus was worshipped as a god of heat, light and prosperity. The religion was practiced among the non-Fey as well as Elves. It was banned during the early years of the Dominion. The symbol of the faith was a pair of cupped hands holding a burning flame. The cult promoted harmony among the different races and a communal agrarian lifestyle. Their primary holiday was on the winter solstice, when worshippers would perform fire dances to bring the return of the sun.

After being banned, some devotees of the faith continued to worship in secret. The faith remained in practice in small circles but has been all but eradicated by Dominion inquisitions. Anyone found to be worshipping Telerus inside the Dominion is sentenced to a lifetime of hard labor in state-operated work camps.

Disciples of Telerus held artifacts of the god that were imbued with solar energy in the form of heat, smoke and flame. They often employed fire elementals as servants to their causes, and were masters of incendiary magic.

The air in this room smells musty, as if it hasnt been stirred in quite a long time, and the walls are painted with a motif of dancing flames and handprints. The room is outfitted with a long wooden table and two sturdy wooden benches. On the wall, a rack of long linen cloaks are hung, dyed a deep orange hue and emblazoned with a hand holding a flame. In the corner, an automaton man sits completely still.

text.p: This room used to serve as a cloak and guard room for the cult of Telerus. A bag of 1d30 GP worth of coins is on the table, as well as some old dirty dishes and a wineskin.

In the corner of the room sitting on the far bench is an antique security golem. It is constructed from wood, metal and ceramic components and has the symbol of Telerus scribed on its chest. Currently, its red energem power source is completely dead, and it cannot turn on or function until it is recharged or else replaced with a new one. Once running the golem acts as a guard for the entire sub basement, patrolling the area. Anyone not wearing the cloak or signet of Telerus it designates as a threat and proceeds to engage in combat with. A magic caster of sufficient skill could attempt to reprogram the energem to give it new directives. Follow the guidelines for energem impressions for more information on reprogramming it.

p.i: This room features a lofty wooden ceiling and a set of stone stairs leading up to a ladder, which ascends to a trap door. Along the walls are inset bookshelves that run all the way up, set with row upon row of dusty books and scrolls.

text.p: This area is the basement of an Elven book shop. The room is 30 feet tall, and the floor-to-ceiling bookshelves are lined with the backstock of the shop on the surface above.

After finding this area via the sewers, the kobolds have secured the route for their smuggling operation. At the time the party enters the room, three winged kobolds named Pree, Ritt, and Rika are in the area. They are significantly better organized than the kobolds in area D and will coordinate their efforts to attack the party. Once one of them becomes bloodied, one or more of them will attempt to flee to area L to inform the kobold mother and other smugglers there. The Kobolds will use the upper shelves in the room as perches, tossing heavy books as thrown weapons.

There are countless old books and scrolls in this room on all sorts of topics. If someone takes an hour to peruse they can find a book on almost any subject. There is a 1D10 chance of them finding a random scroll of 1d4 levels.

A DC15 Investigation Check will uncover a hollowed out book marked with the symbol of Telerus. Inside the book is a signet of Telerus, a small medallion in the shape of a sun with cupped hands holding a flame.

At the top of the 10 foot high set of stairs against the north wall of the room is a ladder that climbs an additional 30 feet into a shaft in the ceiling, ending at a heavy wooden trap door that has been secured by the kobolds with a large metal padlock (DC 25 to pick). Hikara holds the only key to it.

p.i: The vaulted stone roof of this room is painted with marbled red and black, evoking flame and smoke. Two massive columns flanked by stone galleries support it on either side of the entrance. In the center of the room, a lower area seems to have been flooded, and murky water now pools here. At the far end of the space rises a dias, upon which a large stone statue of a figure in a hooded cloak stands facing the entrance. A makeshift wooden causeway has been built between the entrance and the dias. The room reeks of mildew and kobolds.

text.p: This room used to be a secret shrine to Telerus, but has now become a base of operations for the Kobold clan that is smuggling through the book shop. Hikara, the Kobold Mother acting as the clans matriarch, uses the space as a lair and keeps her guards here. Brynn Belana, the granddaughter of the bookshop owner, is locked in a wooden cage next to the statue. Hikara has been keeping her hostage to act as collateral for their continued secrecy.

The room is split into north, south and west sections with the center of the room filled with 5 foot deep water. The north and south sections are used by the guards to launch ranged attacks at any intruders who attempt to enter the room. The Kobold Mother stays with the hostage in the west section. She will use Brynn as a shield against ranged attacks, and if cornered she will threaten to hurt the girl unless allowed to escape.

Hikara is significantly craftier and more intelligent than her offspring, and has been coordinating the sales of their contraband to the merchant Quell. She intends to meet him the next night to handle the sale of the basilisk blood shipment in area E.

Brynn has been locked in the cage in this room for several weeks, after having been kidnapped from her grandfathers bookstore above. She is filthy and unkempt. She is 8 years old, and still has the elongated ears of an early stage nymph. Upon seeing the party she will call out desperately for help. If freed from the cage she will stick closely to whoever is helping her, and will beg them to take her back to her grandfather.
Next to Brynn's cage is a stash box containing Hikara's loot.

The Kobolds have built a makeshift wooden walkway to span the flooded section of the room. However, the structure is poorly built and is coming apart, with several of the boards only balancing in place. Attempting to walk or stand on the left half of the structure requires a DC15 acrobatics check in order to avoid falling into the sewer water below.
A crocodile lives in the murky water under the bridge (DC 15 perception to notice when not moving). Anyone who falls off the bridge into the water will provoke it to attack.

This statue of Telerus stands 12 feet tall at the top of a stepped dias that rises an additional 3 feet above the floor. The hands and upper portion of the statue are stained with soot from the rituals the cult used to perform here. Starting a fire in the cupped hands of the statue will cause the false wall behind it to move aside.

This wall is non-magic and made of the same material as the rest of the walls in the area. There are no markings to indicate a passage, and the Kobolds have not discovered that it hides a secret passage. A DC20 investigation will reveal minor scuffs on the floor and a thin crack to indicate that it moves.

p.i: The end for this dark flagstoned corridor opens into an octagonal room with two large stone statues appearing as armored knights. They face the center of the room, where a reinforced metal chest is bolted to the floor. The front of the chest is painted with cupped hands holding flame.

text.p: This hidden shrine holds relics of Telerus. Inside the metal chest are wooden cases containing a circlet of blasting, an eversmoking bottle, and three captured fire elementals in gems. In the case that someone not wearing a cloak of Telerus attempts to touch or open the reliquary, the two guardian statues in the room will shoot intersecting jets of flame in the square in front of the chest.

category.name: ATD - M_2 Gala of The Masks

text.p: Nestled in the middle of a block of shops in the densly populated Scale Market district on the south side of the city, The Resistance's Drostellan headquarters is hidden in plain sight. The surrounding businesses are either in league with, or paid off by the resistance and offer varying degrees of support to members looking to procure supplies

layer.name: tokens/clawfoot.png@DD Eberron Rising From the Last War - DM

token.name: Clawfoot
token.prototype: tokens/clawfoot.png@DD Eberron Rising From the Last War - DM

description.p: This spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, Aura of Vitality, written in a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class's spell list, you can read the scroll and cast its spell without providing any material components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. Casting the spell by reading the scroll requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.

If the spell is on your class's spell list but of a higher level than you can normally cast, you must make an ability check using your spellcasting ability to determine whether you cast it successfully. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a failed check, the spell disappears from the scroll with no other effect.
Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and the scroll itself crumbles to dust.
This spell scroll's saving throw DC 15 and attack bonus +7.

A wizard spell on a spell scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When a spell is copied from a spell scroll, the copier must succeed on an Intelligence (Arcana) check with a DC equal to 10 + the spell's level. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.

id-00002.name: Scroll of Aura of Vitality
id-00002.nonidentified: Only the best quality parchment has been used in this scroll and clearly the author was a master of calligraphy.

description.p: Arcane Barrel: You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls you make with this weaon.
Overload: Once per turn before you make an attack roll, you may choose to expend a spell slot of 3rd level or lower to deal extra damage.
1st level: 2d6 force
2nd level: 4d6 force
3rd level: 6d6 force
Mana Pistols require a yellow energem battery in order to power their attacks. One battery holds enough charge for 12 uses a day.

id-00001.name: Mana Pistol
id-00001.nonidentified: A typical small firearm, used by enforcers in the Fey Dominion.

description.p: Scrap mechanical pieces that can be used by a tinker to craft devices.

Once an Energem battery has been depleted of Mana, it becomes inert and is unable to hold any charge. However, any imprinted spells on the gems will persist. Once depleted it may be restored at a Mana Confluence by a trained Artificer.

Each time a battery is restored, the overall capacity is diminished by a factor of half. Likewise, there is a compounding chance that the gems will destabilize, randomly resulting in a Mana Implosion during use.
In Yellow Energem batteries this manifests as a small burst of sound and energy, dealing 1d4 radiant damage to anyone within 5 feet.

Red Energem batteries create significantly larger implosions, dealing 3d10 radiant damage to anyone within 30 feet and creating a Mana Dead Zone with a radius of 100 feet. Depleted Red Energem is often used in the crafting of Mana Bombs by resistance forces for this reason.

Blue Energem has no known depletion rate, seeming to have a near infinite ability to output energy once initially charged. However it can be overloaded, forcing an implosion to devastating effect. Mana Bombs powered by Blue Energem have been known to destroy entire buildings, as in the First Uprising when the Temple of Ascendance in Lotus was razed by the Halflings.

id-00005.name: Energem Battery, Yellow (Depleted)
id-00005.nonidentified: A yellow energem battery that can no longer hold a charge. Upon close inspection, the battery emits a faint humming.

description.p: Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owners will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage. Once an imparted spell is used it is removed from the weapon. Only one spell can be stored at a time.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a patch of green slime. You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.

The ability has no effect on concealing lipreading.

description.p: Oil or spirits contained in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. When you use it, you can specify whether or not the cloth stopper is lit (requires ignition source).

As an action, you can splash this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered. If the target takes any fire damage before it dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage. Miss: A patch of flammable liquid covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.

You can also empty this flask on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, it burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
A powerful sedative. Often used to numb pain for surgery, it is extremely popular recreationally as well due to its addictive nature.

One dose completely removes all sensation of pain in the body, as well as creating a euphoric emotion in the user. It grants 1d6 temporary hit points and the user temporarily immune to being fatigued, frightened, petrified, paralyzed, stunned or exhausted.

After taking a dose, the user can move and act normally for another hour, enduring even debilitating pain. Afterwards they proceed to fall into a deep sleep for the following 4 hours, during which time it is almost impossible to wake them.

Every time a user takes this drug they run a 1d4 risk of becoming addicted. If a dose of Basilisk Blood isn't consumed once per day by an addict, they are afflicted with level 3 exhaustion (Disadvantage on ability checks, speed halved, disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws). An addiction can only be cured via magical means.
Each vial contains three doses.

id-00014.name: Basilisk Blood (Vial)

description.p: This round crystal structure houses the sapient energy of a water elemental. Once reanimated, the water elemental will resume whatever state it was in prior to becoming inert.

Absorbing soles: While wearing these boots, you do not suffer any falling damage and land on your feet when fallinf 60ft. or less.

Tightrope: As an action you can lift the Gap Closer overhead and shoot 2 bolts attached to a 50ft steel wire in opposite directions. Make a ranged attack roll for both bolts. On two successful hits you can hold on to the device and use your movement to travel between the two points at 50ft. per round. As a bonus action you can make the device detach and reel in both bolts.
If you hit a creature with one of the bolts it can release itself by making a successful Strength saving throw (DC 10)

Crystal/Ice: 13
Wood/Bone: 15
Stone: 17
Metal: 19

text.p: Pronouns: They/Them
Race: Drow (Dark Elf)
Class: Warlock
Faction: The New Culture (sub-division of Brotherhood of Knives)

You belong to the Guild of Illusionists, a membership of Gnomish artisans, tinkers and wizards devoted to the craft of mechanical and magical facsimile. You began as an apprentice in your childhood and recently graduated to journeyman status. The guild has always served the Dominion as servants to the desires of the High Fey, and because of your membership you have the rare license to practice magic for your craft.

Your patron is known only to you as "The Undying", a nameless entity reborn deep beneath the earth epochs ago. It has haunted you for as long as you can remember in the depths of your nightly trances. You are mostly left to your own devices with no interference from it, though you sometimes dread the demands it will make when it does appear. You must occasionally conduct bizarre rituals to maintain your pact with it; as a consequence you display outward symptoms of a strange disease but suffer no ill effects from it.

You were orphaned at an early age and spent your childhood alone, fending for yourself on the streets. While you barely scraped by alive, it led to you developing superior skills as a cat burglar. Your proficiencies caught the attention of the Dust Clan, an elite group of merceneries specilizing in stealth operations. After signing a contract of engagement, you joined their ranks as a thief for hire.
Fathers family name is Na'Delvoria

text.p: Sculpted from clay, this bulky golem stands head and shoulders taller than most human-sized creatures. It is human shaped, but its proportions are off.

Clay golems are often divinely endowed with purpose by priests of great faith. However, clay is a weak vessel for life force. If the golem is damaged, the elemental spirit bound into it can break free. Such a golem runs amok, smashing everything around it until it is destroyed or completely repaired.

Golems are made from humble materials-clay, flesh and bones, iron, or stone-but they possess astonishing power and durability. A golem has no ambitions, needs no sustenance, feels no pain, and knows no remorse. An unstoppable juggernaut, it exists to follow its creator's orders, and it protects or attacks as that creator demands.

To create a golem, one requires a manual of golems (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). The comprehensive illustrations and instructions in a manual detail the process for creating a golem of a particular type.

Elemental Spirit in Material Form. The construction of a golem begins with the building of its body, requiring great command of the craft of sculpting, stonecutting, ironworking, or surgery. Sometimes a golem's creator is the master of the art, but often the individual who desires a golem must enlist master artisans to do the work.

After constructing the body from clay, flesh, iron, or stone, the golem's creator infuses it with a spirit from the Elemental Plane of Earth. This tiny spark of life has no memory, personality, or history. It is simply the impetus to move and obey. This process binds the spirit to the artificial body and subjects it to the will of the golem's creator.

Ageless Guardians. Golems can guard sacred sites, tombs, and treasure vaults long after the deaths of their creators, carrying out their appointed tasks for all eternity while brushing off physical damage and ignoring all but the most potent spells.
A golem can be created with a special amulet or other item that allows the possessor of the item to control the golem. Golems whose creators are long dead can thus be harnessed to serve a new master.

Blind Obedience. When its creator or possessor is on hand to command it, a golem performs flawlessly. If the golem is left without instructions or is incapacitated, it continues to follow its last orders to the best of its ability. When it can't fulfill its orders, a golem might react violently-or stand and do nothing. A golem that has been given conflicting orders sometimes alternates between them.
A golem can't think or act for itself. Though it understands its commands perfectly, it has no grasp of language beyond that understanding, and can't be reasoned with or tricked with words.
Constructed Nature. A golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

id-00002.desc: Whenever the golem starts its turn with 20 hit points or fewer, roll a d6. On a 6, the golem goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the golem attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the golem attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the golem goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.
id-00002.name: Berserk

id-00003.desc: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.
id-00003.name: Immutable Form

id-00004.desc: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
id-00004.name: Magic Resistance

id-00005.desc: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.
id-00005.name: Magic Weapons

id-00001.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 120 feet
You hurl a mote of fire at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 fire damage. A flammable object hit by this spell ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.
This spell's damage increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17th level (4d10).
id-00001.name: Fire Bolt - Cantrip (At will)

id-00002.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, M (a firefly or phosphorescent moss)
Duration: 1 hour
Range: Touch
You touch one object that is no larger than 10 feet in any dimension. Until the spell ends, the object sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. The light can be colored as you like. Completely covering the object with something opaque blocks the light. The spell ends if you cast it again or dismiss it as an action.
If you target an object held or worn by a hostile creature, that creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw to avoid the spell.
id-00002.name: Light - Cantrip (At will)

id-00003.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: 1 minute
Range: 30 feet
A spectral, floating hand appears at a point you choose within range. The hand lasts for the duration or until you dismiss it as an action. The hand vanishes if it is ever more than 30 feet away from you or if you cast this spell again.
You can use your action to control the hand. You can use the hand to manipulate an object, open an unlocked door or container, stow or retrieve an item from an open container, or pour the contents out of a vial. You can move the hand up to 30 feet each time you use it.
The hand can't attack, activate magic items, or carry more than 10 pounds.
id-00003.name: Mage Hand - Cantrip (At will)

id-00004.desc:
Level: 0
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Up to 1 hour
Range: 10 feet
This spell is a minor magical trick that novice spellcasters use for practice. You create one of the following magical effects within range:
You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as a shower of sparks, a puff of wind, faint musical notes, or an odd odor.
You instantaneously light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.
You instantaneously clean or soil an object no larger than 1 cubic foot.
You chill, warm, or flavor up to 1 cubic foot of nonliving material for 1 hour.
You make a color, a small mark, or a symbol appear on an object or a surface for 1 hour.
You create a nonmagical trinket or an illusory image that can fit in your hand and that lasts until the end of your next turn.

If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its non-instantaneous effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.
id-00004.name: Prestidigitation - Cantrip (At will)

id-00005.desc:
Level: 1 (Ritual)
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes
Range: Self
For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any.
The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.
id-00005.name: Detect Magic - 1st level (4 slots)

id-00006.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a piece of cured leather)
Duration: 8 hours
Range: Touch
You touch a willing creature who isn't wearing armor, and a protective magical force surrounds it until the spell ends. The target's base AC becomes 13 + its Dexterity modifier. The spell ends if the target dons armor or if you dismiss the spell as an action.
id-00006.name: Mage Armor - 1st level (4 slots)

id-00007.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 120 feet
You create three glowing darts of magical force. Each dart hits a creature of your choice that you can see within range. A dart deals 1d4 + 1 force damage to its target. The darts all strike simultaneously, and you can direct them to hit one creature or several.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the spell creates one more dart for each slot level above 1st.
id-00007.name: Magic Missile - 1st level (4 slots)

id-00008.desc:
Level: 1
Casting Time: 1 reaction, which you take when you are hit by an attack or targeted by the magic missile spell
Components: V, S
Duration: 1 round
Range: Self
An invisible barrier of magical force appears and protects you. Until the start of your next turn, you have a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from magic missile.
id-00008.name: Shield - 1st level (4 slots)

id-00009.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 bonus action
Components: V
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: Self
Briefly surrounded by silvery mist, you teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see.
id-00009.name: Misty Step - 2nd level (3 slots)

id-00010.desc:
Level: 2
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, M (a snake's tongue and either a bit of honeycomb or a drop of sweet oil)
Duration: Concentration, up to 8 hours
Range: 30 feet
You suggest a course of activity (limited to a sentence or two) and magically influence a creature you can see within range that can hear and understand you.
Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this effect. The suggestion must be worded in such a manner as to make the course of action sound reasonable.
Asking the creature to stab itself, throw itself onto a spear, immolate itself, or do some other obviously harmful act ends the spell.
The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it pursues the course of action you described to the best of its ability. The suggested course of action can continue for the entire duration. If the suggested activity can be completed in a shorter time, the spell ends when the subject finishes what it was asked to do. You can also specify conditions that will trigger a special activity during the duration. For example, you might suggest that a knight give her warhorse to the first beggar she meets. If the condition isn't met before the spell expires, the activity isn't performed.
If you or any of your companions damage the target, the spell ends.
id-00010.name: Suggestion - 2nd level (3 slots)

id-00011.desc:
Level: 3
Casting Time: 1 reaction, which you take when you see a creature within 60 feet of you casting a spell
Components: S
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 60 feet
You attempt to interrupt a creature in the process of casting a spell. If the creature is casting a spell of 3rd level or lower, its spell fails and has no effect. If it is casting a spell of 4th level or higher, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a success, the creature's spell fails and has no effect.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the interrupted spell has no effect if its level is less than or equal to the level of the spell slot you used.
id-00011.name: Counterspell - 3rd level (3 slots)

id-00012.desc:
Level: 3
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a tiny ball of bat guano and sulfur)
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 150 feet
A bright streak flashes from your pointing finger to a point you choose within range and then blossoms with a low roar into an explosion of flame. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 8d6 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The fire spreads around corners. It ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.
id-00012.name: Fireball - 3rd level (3 slots)

id-00013.desc:
Level: 3
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a wing feather from any bird)
Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes
Range: Touch
You touch a willing creature. The target gains a flying speed of 60 feet for the duration. When the spell ends, the target falls if it is still aloft, unless it can stop the fall.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 3rd.
id-00013.name: Fly - 3rd level (3 slots)

id-00014.desc:
Level: 4
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
Range: Touch
You or a creature you touch becomes invisible until the spell ends. Anything the target is wearing or carrying is invisible as long as it is on the target's person.
id-00014.name: Greater Invisibility - 4th level (3 slots)

id-00015.desc:
Level: 4
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a pinch of dust and a few drops of water)
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: 300 feet
A hail of rock-hard ice pounds to the ground in a 20-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within range. Each creature in the cylinder must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage and 4d6 cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Hailstones turn the storm's area of effect into difficult terrain until the end of your next turn.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the bludgeoning damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 4th.
id-00015.name: Ice Storm - 4th level (3 slots)

id-00016.desc:
Level: 5
Casting Time: 1 action
Components: V, S, M (a small crystal or glass cone)
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: Self (60-foot cone)
A blast of cold air erupts from your hands. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 8d8 cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature killed by this spell becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.
id-00016.name: Cone of Cold - 5th level (1 slot)

text.p: Mages spend their lives in the study and practice of magic. Good-aligned mages offer counsel to nobles and others in power, while evil mages dwell in isolated sites to perform unspeakable experiments without interference.

Any spellcaster that can cast the find familiar spell (such as an archmage or mage) is likely to have a familiar. The familiar can be one of the creatures described in the spell (see the Player's Handbook) or some other Tiny monster, such as a crawling claw, imp, pseudodragon, or quasit.

id-00001.desc:
The mage is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence. The mage has the following wizard spells prepared:
Cantrips (at will): fire bolt, light, mage hand, prestidigitation 
1st level (4 slots): detect magic, mage armor, magic missile, shield
2nd level (3 slots): misty step, suggestion 
3rd level (3 slots): counterspell, fireball, fly 
4th level (3 slots): greater invisibility, ice storm 
5th level (1 slot): cone of cold
id-00001.name: Spellcasting

id-00001.carriedby: Trislana Folkmar [330], Gunther Brindleset [277], J [76], Zin Do'Aavir [236]
id-00001.name: GP

id-00082.name: Backpack

id-00001.name: Zin Do'Aavir
id-00001.senses: Superior Darkvision 120\nDetect Magic at will\nSunlight Sensitivity
id-00001.specialdefense: Save adv. vs disease, charm\nImmune to sleep\nAmong The Dead

id-00002.name: Gunther Brindleset
id-00002.specialdefense: Save adv. vs magic: INT, WIS, CHA

id-00003.name: J
id-00003.specialdefense: Immune to surprise\nNo adv. on ATK by hidden enemy

id-00004.name: Trislana Folkmar
id-00004.specialdefense: Save adv. vs disease, charm\nImmune to sleep

description.p: For your first mission, the Resistance has tasked you with finding and securing a smuggler's route under the Drostella border wall. It is rumored the entrance is somewhere near the tavern known as The Grinning Gander.

When you take the Dash action, you gain extra Movement for the current turn. The increase equals your speed, after applying any modifiers. With a speed of 30 feet, for example, you can move up to 60 feet on Your Turn if you dash.

Any increase or decrease to your speed changes this additional Movement by the same amount. If your speed of 30 feet is reduced to 15 feet, for instance, you can move up to 30 feet this turn if you dash.
If you take the Disengage action, your Movement doesnt provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn.
Rot grub larvae mixed with dessicated flesh bits in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a swarm of rot grubs. Miss: A swarm of rot grubs covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
Green slime contained in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can splash this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a patch of green slime (see chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide). Miss: A patch of green slime covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also pour a flask on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.

id-00002.label: Basilisk Blood; IMMUNE: Fatigued, Frightened, Petrified, Paralyzed, Stunned, Exhausted;

description.p: A powerful sedative. Often used to numb pain for surgery, it is extremely popular recreationally as well due to its addictive nature.

One dose completely removes all sensation of pain in the body, as well as creating a euphoric emotion in the user. It grants 1d6 temporary hit points and the user temporarily immune to being fatigued, frightened, petrified, paralyzed, stunned or exhausted.

After taking a dose, the user can move and act normally for another hour, enduring even debilitating pain. Afterwards they proceed to fall into a deep sleep for the following 4 hours, during which time it is almost impossible to wake them.

Every time a user takes this drug they run a 1d4 risk of becoming addicted. If a dose of Basilisk Blood isn't consumed once per day by an addict, they are afflicted with level 3 exhaustion (Disadvantage on ability checks, speed halved, disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws). An addiction can only be cured via magical means.
Each vial contains three doses.

Smoke leaks from the lead-stoppered mouth of this brass bottle, which weighs 1 pound. When you use an action to remove the stopper, a cloud of thick smoke pours out in a 60-foot radius from the bottle. The cloud's area is heavily obscured. Each minute the bottle remains open and within the cloud, the radius increases by 10 feet until it reaches its maximum radius of 120 feet.

The cloud persists as long as the bottle is open. Closing the bottle requires you to speak its command word as an action. Once the bottle is closed, the cloud disperses after 10 minutes. A moderate wind (11 to 20 miles per hour) can also disperse the smoke after 1 minute, and a strong wind (21 or more miles per hour) can do so after 1 round.

id-00007.name: Item: Eversmoking Bottle
id-00007.shortdescription: A strangely shaped brass bottle with a leaden stopper through which a thin stream of smoke continually escapes.

description.p: These combustion powered boots are used by Dwarven cave explorers in The Deep to jump large distances safely. Each use of the boots consumes one measure of blasting powder.

Lift off: When you are standing on solid ground, you can use a bonus action to activate these boots. When you do, you launch up to 45ft. in a vertical line upward. After using this feature, you can not use it again for 1 minute.
Absorbing soles: While wearing these boots, you do not suffer any falling damage and land on your feet when fallinf 60ft. or less.

id-00008.name: Item: Dwarven Chasm Jumpers
id-00008.shortdescription: A pair of clunky boots with metal components attached to the heels.

description.p: Scrap mechanical pieces that can be used by a tinker to craft devices.
Green slime contained in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a patch of green slime. Miss: A patch of green slime covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a swarm of rot grubs. Miss: A swarm of rot grubs covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
This gemstone is opaque light pink in color.
This gemstone is opaque light and dark blue with yellow flecks in color.
This gemstone is opaque gray-black in color.
This gemstone is opaque mottled deep blue in color.
Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owners will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage. Once an imparted spell is used it is removed from the weapon. Only one spell can be stored at a time.
Rusted weapons suffer a penalty of -1 to attack and damage rolls. A rusted weapon can be repaired to good condition by a blacksmith or anyone proficient with smith's tools.
This gem contains a mote of elemental energy. When you use an action to break the gem, a fire elemental is summoned as if you had cast the conjure elemental spell, and the gem's magic is lost.

id-00001.name: Red Elemental Gem
id-00001.nonidentified: A crystal clear corundum which, when you look into it, seems to contain a mote of something bright deep inside its core.

description.p: While wearing this circlet, you can use an action to cast the scorching ray spell with it. When you make the spell's attacks, you do so with an attack bonus of +5. The circlet can't be used this way again until the next dawn.

id-00002.name: Circlet of Blasting
id-00002.nonidentified: Made of gold this circlet has a stylised sun symbol set with a large cut stone at its centre.

description.p: As an action, a creature can light a stick of dynamite and throw it at a point up to 60 feet away. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 3d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A character can bind sticks of dynamite together so they explode at the same time. Each additional stick increases the damage by 1d6 (to a maximum of 10d6) and the burst radius by 5 feet (to a maximum of 20 feet).

Dynamite can be rigged with a longer fuse to explode after a set amount of time, usually 1 to 6 rounds. Roll initiative for the dynamite. After the set number of rounds goes by, the dynamite explodes on that initiative.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
